title: Narayana Murthy calls for $1 billion to be spent annually for 20 years to train retired teachers
description: According to the Infosys cofounder, the teacher training programme should be a year-long affair, where about US$ 100,000 is paid to the retired teachers, who can themselves become trainers over five years.
content: Infosys founder NR Narayana Murthy has called for a yearly investment of at least $1 billion for the next 20 years on training primary and secondary school teachers to push implementation of the National Education Policy (NEP)."One possible way of accelerating NEP’s outcome is to invite 10,000 retired, highly accomplished teachers from the developed world and from India in STEM areas (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) to create 2,500 ‘Train the Teacher’ colleges in our 28 states and 8 union territories,” he said. Murthy was addressing the Infosys Science Foundation (ISF), where the winners of the Infosys Prize 2023 were announced.According to the Infosys cofounder, the teacher training programme should be a year-long affair, where about US$ 100,000 is paid to the retired teachers, who can themselves become trainers over five years.This means the 20-year programme would cost India $1 billion a year and $20 billion over 20 years.“Our nation, targeting a GDP of $5 trillion soon, will not find it a big financial burden,” said Murthy. Quoting Derek Bok, a former President of Harvard University, he added, “If you think education is expensive, try ignorance.”
